pageSummary: We're fundraising for because they provided Chris with end of life care.

story:
Chris was a kind and generous person, who had given to charities regularly. Since Macmillan Cancer Support and Cancer Research UK both played a role in his care, we are confident that donations to these two organisations honour Chris' life and values.

Chris had thyroid cancer, and it was advanced by the time it was discovered in July 2020. He had tumours in many parts of his body, particularly his lungs. He was resolute in his efforts to get treatment that we all hoped would prolong his life. After a successful thyroidectomy, he went home to recuperate, but in the weeks afterwards he started to have breathing troubles that meant he was admitted to hospital. Unfortunately, he passed away suddenly there, which was a shock to those closest to him, who were hours earlier making plans for him to come home to hospice care. His memory lives on through his family and friends. He was deeply loved and will be dearly missed.

pageSummary: Hosting an online Ladies' Lunch because the local annual Ladies' Lunch is cancelled.
pageSummaryWhy: the local annual Ladies' Lunch is cancelled.
story:
At this time of year normally, our little band of friends (known locally as "rent a crowd") would be getting ready to spend a fun-filled Sunday afternoon at a local hotel attending the annual Ladies' Lunch in aid of MacMillan Cancer support. This event organised by team McKeown is extremely well attended and a must on our calendar year. For obvious reasons, there will be no lunch this year. Nevertheless, MacMillan, like so many other charities, need our support. Possibly more than ever. The charity stands to be £175,000,000 down by the end of 2022. 

MacMillan continues to support individuals and their families living with cancer, and many of their nurses were redeployed to provide care in Coronavirus wards throughout the NHS.

Most of us have been touched by cancer at some point in our lives. Our wee group is especially effected this year, and that is why we want to continue to raise funds for this worthwhile charity.

We are intending to run a Home Alone Ladies' Lunch on November 1st at 2pm. We will be buying our tickets as normal, and organising an online/Zoom lunch or afternoon tea on that day. 

This JustGiving page is created for anyone who wants to support our Home Alone Ladies' Lunch. Please contact me if you want to join our Zoom on the day, and I will furnish you with the Login details.

Thank you in anticipation.

story:
--------- KODY'S BWS JOURNEY ---------

- Kody was a week or two old when we realised he had an unusually large tongue.
- Googled babies with large tongues (microglossia) which was one of the symptoms of BWS (Beckwith Wiedemann Symdrome). 

Beckwith Wiedemann Syndrome
This is the most common overgrowth and cancer predisposition disorder. BWS is caused by changes of chromosome 11p15. 5.
Happens 1 in 15,000 births

- Looked into the other symptoms of BWS and realised he had a few.

Symptoms
Kody have:

  • Large size for a newborn (he was born 4 weeks early at 7lb 14oz)
  • An enlarged tongue (macroglossia) [causes problems with feedings, speech and development of the teeth and jaw]
  • Umbilical hernia
  • Red birth mark on his eyelid (nevus flammeus) [can also be on the forehead]
  • Creases in his right ear lobe

other symtoms may be:

  • low blood sugar
  • increased rate of tumor growth.
  • enlargement of some organs.
  • arm or leg larger then the other (hemihypertrophy)

- Was referred to Basildon Hospital from his GP to been analysed by a pediatrician.
- Was advised to have a gentics blood test to confirm.
- Took just over 2months to finally have diagnosis back in April 2020 which then was put down for ultra sound scans on his kidney every 3-4months until Kody is 7years old
- The scans help identify 'Wilms- Kidney tumour' which is very common with BWS under the age of 5years old can be cancerous.
- Was then referred to Great Ormond Street (GOSH) for further help and advice on his microglossia
- After many video calls with the Microglossia / BWS / speech and language Teams we are now on the list to undergo his tongue reduction surgery with Juling Ong beginning of 2021 

Kody turnt one in October 2020
- We still have a few appointments coming up and scans are still regular.
- Been advised to stay on puree foods due to not being able to chew/breaking down any food

I see more awareness in America than the U.K so would love to do my bit to try and spread the word of BWS.
I think Kody has a minor case of the syndrome. I have spoken to parents whos children have not been so fortunate.

So this is my misson....... To help and fundraise for the Amazing childrens charity (GOSH) and to spread as much awareness as i can i will be challenging myself from the 16th Oct 2020, 10mins of an intense core exercise everyday up till his Operation date (which isnt known yet but will be next year).
This will be recorded on an app and updated with proof!!!!!!! 
Will also be selling silicone wristbands very soon!!!!

Thank you for taking your time to read 'Kody's Journey' so far <3

Stay Strong, Together We Can, Together We Will
You are never alone

story:
Chris was a kind and generous person, who had given to charities regularly. Since Macmillan Cancer Support and Cancer Research UK both played a role in his care, we are confident that donations to these two organisations honour Chris' life and values.

Chris had thyroid cancer, and it was advanced by the time it was discovered in July 2020. He had tumours in many parts of his body, particularly his lungs. He was resolute in his efforts to get treatment that we all hoped would prolong his life. story:
On the 2nd November, I am hiking up the highest peak on each of Hong Kong's 3 'continents': Lantau Peak on Lantau Island; Tai Mo Shan in Kowloon; and Victoria Peak on Hong Kong Island. Each will be climbed from approximately sea level and the total ascent will be 2,443 metres. For context, that's twice the height of Ben Nevis, 500 metres more than Mt Ventoux, and half the height of either Mont Blanc or Mt Whitney.

I am doing this for an excellent cause and I need your donations, please.

The arrival of COVID has pushed cancer off the radar. Hospital admissions for cancer treatment in the UK tell a terrible story. Compared to the 5-year average, prostate cancer admissions during COVID have fallen 64%, breast cancer admissions have fallen 30% and admissions for lung cancer (the #1 killer) have fallen 43%. This isn't because cancer has suddenly disappeared. The huge global focus on COVID has caused cancer diagnosis and treatment to be cancelled or postponed. However, Cancer isn't waiting for a vaccine for COVID, and it isn't on lockdown.

Please donate now, to support Cancer research, because cures don't grow on trees.

story:

Like many people who have been effected by cancer, the pain is unexplainable to the person effected but also impacts the loved ones around during and definitely after the inevitable...... Still chunky but at least Im not a walking heart attack anymore. 

So 2021 is the year I want to fulfill my promise to my dad. The C2C is the first milestone in that but the biggest driving force is raising money to contribute to the research so that in the future many other hero's and families are spared the pain that cancer unfortunately causes now. As Tesco say, every little helps.

eventName: RAF Police bench press the RAF Red Arrows
story:
Hi, 

My name is Corporal Oliver Jinks and I am currently serving in Her Majesty’s Royal Air Force (RAF) as a Royal Air Force Policeman. 

On the 21st October 2020, I lost my Grandfather to Pancreatic Cancer, after he had courageously fought a long and painful battle with the illness.

I was determined not to let my Grandfather pass on in vain, so I decided to set up an event and try to raise funding towards defeating Cancer.

For the event, I have arranged for a team of 6 RAF Police (including myself) to attempt to bench press the combined weight of the 9 RAF Red Arrows Jets (32.65 tons) in the shortest time possible. This will be a difficult yet achievable challenge, which will be completed on the 26th November 2020.

I wanted to connect my event to the RAF as 2020 is the 80th Anniversary of the Battle of Britain, which saw our tiny nation defeat the bigger fast approaching enemy. I want to pay homage to those heroes and contribute in the fight against the invisible enemies (illnesses) we have to live with every single day.

Throughout this unprecedented time, charities have been overshadowed and hit hard by COVID-19. I want to show that these charities have not been forgotten and are still completing life saving work on a daily basis!

I am aware that completing this challenge will not bring back my Grandfather. However, my event has been set up to fund research to save our future family members and defeat Cancer. I understand that I can’t build Rome in one day. I just want you to join me in laying down some bricks.

To achieve this we need to work together and raise as much money as we can so please like, share, post, recommend and most of all donate!

Thank you very much for your time and stay safe!

Oliver Jinks

After falling extremely ill at the age of 13 I always wanted to defeat the odds, whether it be walking again after being paralysed or getting into university with little qualification I knew I what wanted to achieve. As soon as I saw the Three peaks challenge I knew I had to do it. I wanted to prove that to my self and to others that I am strong and well despite my illness this doesn't make me weak. I have extreme empathy for the work the charity undertakes for those who are terminally ill as I understand the true work that takes place for the people and the families to ensure it is as comfortable and stress free environment as possible.

We will walk through the lovely and familiar Gledhow Valley woods on an easy and family-friendly path.
